p: Montesano et al. [ 6] evaluated the effect of posidonia compost-based substrates as a potential growing media for potted sea fennel cultivation ( Figure 6). Following the harvest carried out 60 days after transplantation, these Authors found an average yield of about 5.4 g DW plant âˆ’1 without significant differences between various substrates, suggesting the possibility to replace peat substrates with renewable media without a negative effect on yield and quality. Furthermore, these Authors hypothesized that the halophyte aptitude of sea fennel can help to overcome the limitations posed by the high salinity of some compost-based growing media [ 6].
